text.p: - Slovenia's political parties have to issue official lists of candidates for November 10 general elections by October 26.

- Investigations by numerous parliamentary committees over the past four years have not resulted in any legal action and are therefore not expected to have any influence on the coming general elections.
- Local communities need more money to carry out their duties, the minister of local affairs said.
- Slovenian Prime Minister Janez Drnovsek opened a new Telekom building in Maribor on Sunday.
- About 18.6 percent of Slovenians have not yet used their privatisation vouchers which are set to expire in June 1997.
- Former Slovenian Defence Minister Janez Jansa said in an interview with Reuters that Slovenia ignored a U.N. arms embargo imposed on ex-Yugoslav republics.
- Analysts say authorities should increase control of tax payments in order to help the economy.
- Slovenia has about 30 different religious groups, most of which believe the Catholic Church should not have a special status among them.
